column4: im looking for some one who can do a fancy renaming on all files in a folder. I have a folder full of NES roms and all the files have (USA) in the file name. I need a one line command to remove  (USA) from the file names
i do not have a rename feature im running a stipped down version of ubuntu   its xbmc-LIVE
then use pure bash « for f in *; do mv -- "$f" --target "${f/USA/}" ; done
second time ---> then use pure bash « for f in *; do mv -- "$f" --target "${f/USA/}" ; done
I copied and pasted your line of text starting at  ---->  and it returned this  -bash: syntax error near unexpected token `do'
you have to copy what is between the « and »
for f in *; do mv -- "$f" --target "${f/USA/}" ; done   returned   ..... filename is not a directory
mv: target `Attack of the Killer Tomatoes ().zip' is not a directory   I got that for each file in the folder
for f in *; do mv -- "$f" "${f/USA/}" ; done
it got rid of USA but left me with ()  in the file name
for f in *; do mv -- "$f" "${f/\(\)/}" ; done
if you want to get rid o (USA) in one go -> for f in *; do mv -- "$f" "${f/\(USA\)/}" ; done
thanks for your help  for a linux n00b like myself googling and trial and error wasn't working
